text:
Dr, Hyman Goldin
Federal Communications Commission
Washington 25, D, C,
July 13, 1962
fP
b
Dear Hy:
1 was pleased to receive the copies of the new FCC forms for educational
broadcasting which Keith Engar sent, and am highly pleased with the job
you and he have done in drafting forms which sommuch better fit the
operation of non-commercial educational broadcasters.
I would prefer to see the Commission identify NETRC and NAEB programs as
coming from a "national or regional program source" than from a "network",
for neither of these organizations, nor the program service they offer
their "affiliated" stations are networks in the sense the Commission has
used in its study of or dealings with networks.
j
In Sec. 3.658 of the Rules, reference is made to Ch, VII,J, of the Report
on Chain Broadcasting. I don*t have a copy of that report currently at
0hand, but the balance of Sec, 3.658 discusses network control over stations
as falling into such matters as: Exclusivity of Affiliation; Exclusivity
of Territory; Term of Affiliation; Option Time; Right to Reject Programs;
Network Ownership of Stations; and Control of Station Rates. None of these
matters are in any way related to the program service offered by NETRC or
J NAEB to the stations.
I know that NETRC is attempting to create for itself an image of the "4th
Network", but I am in complete disagreement with them on this, for they
are not, nor do I think they wil ever be a network in the accepted trade
sense. I think there is great danger to the proper development of a
non-commercial educational service to encourage, in any way, the network
concept, with its implied control over programs. The network concept is
being promoted by NETRC in their desire to find commercial underwriting
for their programs -- and I think this is most inimical to the development
of a non-commercial service.
The program services available to the stations from NETRC or NAEB are, in
my opinion, no different than the program packages available to commercial
stations from non-network sources. I do not mean, in any way, to imply a
dissatisfaction with the NETRC programs, but their service is not "network".
I do not want NETRC or the stations which use their service to be marked with
the stigma whitah is growing up around "network programming"
Mrs. Stone joins me in our best regards to you. We thoroughly enjoyed your
visit and the opportunity to become better acquainted.
Sincerely,
Loren B. Stone
